conclusion: Understanding refraction and Snell's Law is key to solving the problem.
The diver sees the scenery above the water in an inverted cone shape with vertex angle α.
We need to find the speed of light in water, given the speed of light in vacuum is C.
Snell's Law relates angles of incidence and refraction to the speeds of light in different media.
Refractive index n is defined as n = C/v, where v is the speed of light in the medium.
The cone seen by the diver is due to total internal reflection.
Critical angle θc is the angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs.
Critical angle is related to refractive indices by sin θc = n2/n1.
Vertex angle α of the cone is related to the critical angle.
Angle α/2 is the angle of refraction at the water-air boundary.
sin(α/2) = 1/n, where n is the refractive index of water.
Speed of light in water v is given by v = C/n.
Substitute n = 1/sin(α/2) into v = C/n to get v = C · sin(α/2).
The propagation speed of light in water is v = C · sin(α/2).
